subtitle: chapter 9 the acceptance of the
Christian conception of life will
emancipate man from miseries of our
pagan life the position of the Christian
people in our days has remained just as
cruel as it was in a time of paganism in
many respects especially in the
oppression of the masses is become even
more cruel and it was in the days of
paganism but between the condition of
men in ancient times and their condition
in our day there is just the difference
that we see in the world of vegetation
between the last days of autumn and the
first days of spring in the autumn the
external lifelessness of nature
corresponds with its inward condition of
death while in this spring the external
lifelessness is in sharp contrast with
the internal state of reviving and
passing in new forms of life in the same
way the similarity between the ancient
heathen life and the life of today is
merely external the inward condition of
men in the times of hedonism was
absolutely different from their inward
conditions at the present time then the
outward condition of cruelty and of
slavery was in complete harmony with the
inner conscience of men and every step
in advance intensified this harmony now
the awkward condition of cruelty and of
slavery is completely contradictory to
the Christian conscience of men and
every step in advance only intensifies
this contradiction humanity is passing
through seemingly unnecessary fruitless
Agony's it is passing through something
like the throes of birth everything is
ready for the new life but still a new
life does not come there seems no way
out of the position and there would be
none except that a man and thereby all
man is gifted with the power form in a
different higher theory of life which
would once frees him from all the bonds
by which he seems in the solidly
fettered and such a theory as a
Christian view of life made known to man
eighteen hundred years ago a man need
only make this theory of his life his
own for the fetters which seemed so into
solidly forged upon him to drop off of
themselves and for him to feel himself
absolutely free just as a bird would
feel himself free a fenced-in place
directly in tools to its wings people
talk about the liberty of the Christian
church about giving or not giving
freedom to Christians underline all
these IDs and expression there is some
strange misconception freedom cannot be
bestowed on or taken from a Christian or
Christians freedom isn't in a
possession of the Christian if we talk
of bestowing freedom on Christians or
withholding it from them we are
obviously taking and talking out of real
Christians but if people who only call
themselves Christians a Christian cannot
fail to be free because the attainment
of the aim he sets before himself cannot
be prevented or even hindered by anyone
or anything let a man only understand
his life as Christianity teaches him to
understand it let him understand that is
that his life belongs not to him not to
his own individuality nor to his family
nor to the state but to him who has sent
him into the world and let him once
understand that he must therefore
fulfill not the law of his own
individuality nor his family nor the
state but the infinite law of him from
whom he has come and he will not only
feel himself absolutely free from every
human power but we'll even cease to
regard such power as it all able to
hamper anyone let a man but realize at
the aim of his life is the fulfillment
of God's law and that law will replace
all other laws for him and he will give
it his sole allegiance so that by the
very allegiance every human law will
lose all binding and controlling power
in his eyes the Christian is independent
of every human authority by the fact
that he regards the divine law of love
implanted in the soul of every man and
brought before his consciousness by
Christ as a soul guide of his life and
other man's also the Christian may be
subjected to external violence he may be
deprived of bodily freedom he may be in
bondage to his passions he who commits
sin is a slave to sin but he cannot be
in bondage in a sense of being forced by
any danger by any threat of external
harm to perform an act which is against
his conscience he cannot be compelled to
do this because the deprivation and
sufferings which form such a powerful
weapon against men of the state
conception of life have not the least
power to compel him deprivation and
suffering take from them the happiness
from which they live but far from
disturbing the happiness of the
Christian which consists in the
consciousness of fulfilling the will of
God
they may even intensify it when they are
inflicted on him for fulfilling as well
and therefore the Christian who is
subject only to the inner divine law not
only cannot carry out the enactment of
the external law which they are not in
agreement with
divine law of love which he acknowledges
as is usually the case with state
obligations he cannot even recognize the

whatever he cannot recognize the duty of
what is called allegiance for a
Christian the oath of allegiance to any
government whatever the very act which
is regarded as the foundation of
existence of the state is a direct

who promises unconditional obedience in
the futures of laws made or to be made
by that very promised is in the most

which means obeying in every
circumstance of life only divine law of

fixed times of Prayer abstention from

that is just the distinction between the
Christian religion and the heathen
religion Christianity does not require
of a man certain definite negative acts
but puts them in a new different
relation to men from which may resolve
the most diverse acts which cannot be
defined beforehand and therefore the
Christian not only cannot promise to
obey the will of any man without knowing
what bill required of the will he not
only cannot obey the changing laws of
them but he cannot even promise to do
anything definite at a certain time or
to abstain from doing anything for a
certain time for he cannot know what at
any time will be required of him by that
Christian law of love obedience to which
constitutes the meaning of life for him
the Christian in promising unconditional
fulfillment of the laws of men in the
future would show plainly by that
promise that the inner law of God does
not constitute for him the sole law of
his life for a Christian to promise

just as all workman bound to one

out every order that might be given him

masters the Christian is independent of
human authority because he acknowledges
God's authority alone his law revealed

voluntarily obeys it and this
independence is gained not by means of
strife not by the destruction of
existing form
of life but only by a change in the
interpretation of life the independence
results first from the Christian
recognizing the law of love revealed to

sufficient for all human relations and
therefore he regards every use of force
as unnecessary and unlawful and
secondary from the fact that these

deprivation and suffering which reduced
the man of the social conception of life
to the necessity of obeying to the
Christian from his different conception

these conditions without striving
against them by force he patiently
endures like sickness hunger and every
other hardship but they cannot serve him

neither shall any man hear his voice in

break and smoking flax Shelly not quench
till he sent forth judgment into victory
the Christian will not dispute with
anyone nor attack anyone no use violence

not only himself be free but will free

he shall know the truth and the truth
shall make you free if there were any

the perfect Liberty that nothing can

he makes the Christian theory of life
his own would be an unmistakable proof
as of truth men and their present
